player_decision.reason: Heads-up in small blind with marginal Jc2c — open-raise to the minimum (20 total) to apply pressure and try to steal the pot without committing many chips. Preserves my large stack while keeping fold equity against the short-stacked big blind.

Heads-up preflop with Kd8c in the big blind facing a 20 bet. Calling 10 gives you favorable pot odds (10 to win 35, break-even around 22%). You have equity vs his range to realize on future streets, so a cheap play to see the flop is the best balance between survival and potential gain.

You have top pair (K on Ks Td 8d) on a dynamic flop with two diamonds. Calling preserves your stack, lets you see the turn and re-evaluate versus a wide opponent range (bigs/broadways, diamonds, draws) without bloating the pot.

My hand is weak (J2 on K-T-8 board) with little draw. I don’t want to commit a large portion of my big lead here. Call to see the turn cheaply, preserve stack advantage and reevaluate with more information.
Turn gives us a set of kings (Kd with Ks Kh on board). We’re ahead of most of Bob’s range and with only 50 chips left, shoving maximizes value and pressure, reducing river risks.

Board (T♣? Td, 8d, Ks, Kh) paired the King on turn and my J♣2♣ has very little showdown equity (only small pair outs). Charlie’s all-in on the paired turn strongly represents Kx/sets; calling a big pot here is high risk. Fold to preserve my large chip lead and maximize tournament win chances.
